text: Heterogeneous expression of Epstein-Barr virus latent proteins in endemic Burkitt 's lymphoma .
Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) - infected cells may sustain three distinct forms of virus latency .

In lymphoblastoid cell lines , six EBV-encoded nuclear antigens ( <extra_id_0> EBNA1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 3A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 3B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 3C <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> -LP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , three latent membrane proteins ( <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 2B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , and two nuclear RNAs ( EBERs ) are expressed .
This form of latency , termed latency III , is also encountered in some posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorders .

In EBV - positive cases of Hodgkin 's disease , the EBERs , <extra_id_0> EBNA1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and the LMPs are expressed ( latency II ) , whereas in Burkitt 's lymphoma ( BL ) only the EBERs and <extra_id_0> EBNA1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have been detected ( latency I ) .
We have studied the expression of EBV proteins in 17 cases of EBV - positive endemic BL by immunohistology .

Expression of <extra_id_0> LMP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was seen in variable proportions of tumor cells in two cases and <extra_id_0> EBNA2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was detected in some tumor cells in three other cases .
Also , the <extra_id_0> BZLF1 trans-activator protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was expressed in a few tumor cells in 6 cases , indicating entry into the lytic cycle .
A phenotypic drift from latency I to latency III has been observed previously in some BL cell lines .
Our results suggest that a similar phenomenon may occur in BL in vivo and indicate that the operational definition of EBV latencies is not easily applied to human tumors .
